bibl.title: Letter from Theodore C. Lyster to Henry Rose Carter, November 18, 1924

div1.p: Lyster comments on Carter's manuscript. He agrees with Carter's theory regarding the origins of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Theodore C. Lyster to Henry Rose Carter, November 18, 1924
div1.opener:
Section III
Below
THEODORE C. LYSTER, M. D.
EUGENE R. LEWIS, M. D.
ISAAC H. JONES, M. D.
SAMUEL D. INGHAM, M. D.
1020 WILSHIRE BOULEVARD
LOS ANGELES
November 18, 1924.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
The Westmoreland,
2121 California Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have read with great interest and delight
Section III of the History of Yellow Fever. It has always been a great
pleasure to read your articles in their course of preparation because it
gives me a double standard from which to form an opinion. Your suggestion
that I read the text and omit the foot notes is far easier said than done,
however, I sincerely did my best to read the text, tempted at all times to
stray to the foot notes, and on the second reading I settled down to
thoroughly enjoy the article with the foot notes. While we were in Washington
as a family we always had a great desire to be able to follow Florida Avenue
from one end of the town to the other; on looking back, I do not believe we
were ever successful, always at some point being diverted on to a side street,
such as “T” street or “W” street. If you have tried this little stunt you
will understand why I refer to it in connection with trying to read the text
of your article without a diversion towards the foot notes.

It seems to me that you have covered the subject
so thoroughly that it does not leave me much upon which to base an argument.
As you know, with Dr. Finlay, I have always been inclined to believe the
American origin. Now that you have assembled the facts, which I must admit
as facts, I am beginning to fear that the Old World interpretation is the more
correct. There are some points of special interest to me:
1. Your explanation of the reason for the
mildness of the disease in the Negro is interesting and is in line with our
knowledge of the lessened susceptibility of those who live in endemic centers;
it seems strange, however, that they would not have acquired an immunity
rather than a lessened susceptibility.
2. The absence of allied species of Aedes
aegypti points strongly to an Old World origin of the yellow fever vector.
Under this heading, do you recall whether any of these allied species have
been used in the attempt to transmit yellow fever? I believe that the common
Stegomyia of India is the lancellotus (I am not quite sure whether this is its
technical name or not). It has always seemed strange to me that the disease
has never spread to India from Africa, and it would argue against this allied
species being a possible vector. I remember some time ago urging Noguchi to
try out this Stegomyia of India, which came about after a discussion between
Darling and myself as to why it has not played a part in the spread of yellow
fever. As far as I know, Noguchi has not had a chance to do this.
Dr. H. R. Carter.
- 2 -
3. The historical close association
in early times between tropical America and West Africa is certainly
brought out well in your quotation from Governor Ovando's petition to
Charles V in 1503. Certainly if Ovando complained of too many slaves
in the colonies, there is little doubt that the slave trade had early
been established.
4. Another interesting point is the
absence of early Mayan and Nahuatl descriptions of yellow fever. While
in Mexico in 1920, Mrs. Nuttall and I thoroughly discussed the possibility
of Nahuatl literature having some reference to a disease such as yellow
fever prior to the Conquest. She has so far been unable to locate any
mention of disease which could be interpreted as yellow fever, which bears
out your opinion.
5. The absence of yellow fever from Cuba
for 138 years after its settlement is decidedly against even a possibility
of an endemic Caribbean center.

When you have completed your notes for the
West Africa side of the question, please be sure and send them to me before
making me make up my mind. There are many points that are far from clear
in the African situation which no doubt will be brought out in your notes.
I will look forward to your article in the Annals of Tropical Medicine and
Parisitology.

With best regards to Miss Laura, and tell
her from me to so regulate your habits of life that you will go through
this winter without endangering yourself tofrom another pneumonic attack. You
have now a mission to complete and it may take several years, and until
that is done, you know, you must remain with us.

We have been having a little flurry of
pneumonic plague, as you know. Perry was here, but I am sorry I did not
have a chance to see him. I have been in hopes he would call me up. He
may do so sometime when he is here in town. I would certainly like to
see him again.

Love to Mrs. Gorgas when you see her, and
best wishes to you and yours.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Theodore C. Lyster, M. D. TCL:HH
